title: Why Startups Condense in America
title_zh: [待翻译] Why Startups Condense in America

paragraphs: May 2006(This essay is derived from a keynote at Xtech.)Startups happen in clusters. There are a lot of them in Silicon Valley and Boston, and few in Chicago or Miami. A country that wants startups will probably also have to reproduce whatever makes these clusters form.I've claimed that the recipe is a great university near a town smart people like.

If you set up those conditions within the US, startups will form as inevitably as water droplets condense on a cold piece of metal. But when I consider what it would take to reproduce Silicon Valley in another country, it's clear the US is a particularly humid environment.

Startups condense more easily here.It is by no means a lost cause to try to create a silicon valley in another country. There's room not merely to equal Silicon Valley, but to surpass it. But if you want to do that, you have to understand the advantages startups get from being in America.1.

The US Allows Immigration.For example, I doubt it would be possible to reproduce Silicon Valley in Japan, because one of Silicon Valley's most distinctive features is immigration. Half the people there speak with accents.

And the Japanese don't like immigration. When they think about how to make a Japanese silicon valley, I suspect they unconsciously frame it as how to make one consisting only of Japanese people. This way of framing the question probably guarantees failure.A silicon valley has to be a mecca for the smart and the ambitious, and you can't have a mecca if you don't let people into it.Of course, it's not saying much that America is more open to immigration than Japan.

Immigration policy is one area where a competitor could do better.2. The US Is a Rich Country.I could see India one day producing a rival to Silicon Valley. Obviously they have the right people: you can tell that by the number of Indians in the current Silicon Valley.

The problem with India itself is that it's still so poor.In poor countries, things we take for granted are missing. A friend of mine visiting India sprained her ankle falling down the steps in a railway station.

When she turned to see what had happened, she found the steps were all different heights. In industrialized countries we walk down steps our whole lives and never think about this, because there's an infrastructure that prevents such a staircase from being built.The US has never been so poor as some countries are now.

There have never been swarms of beggars in the streets of American cities. So we have no data about what it takes to get from the swarms-of-beggars stage to the silicon-valley stage. Could you have both at once, or does there have to be some baseline prosperity before you get a silicon valley?I suspect there is some speed limit to the evolution of an economy.

Economies are made out of people, and attitudes can only change a certain amount per generation. [1]3. The US Is Not (Yet) a Police State.Another country I could see wanting to have a silicon valley is China.

But I doubt they could do it yet either. China still seems to be a police state, and although present rulers seem enlightened compared to the last, even enlightened despotism can probably only get you part way toward being a great economic power.It can get you factories for building things designed elsewhere.

Can it get you the designers, though? Can imagination flourish where people can't criticize the government? Imagination means having odd ideas, and it's hard to have odd ideas about technology without also having odd ideas about politics.

And in any case, many technical ideas do have political implications. So if you squash dissent, the back pressure will propagate into technical fields. [2]Singapore would face a similar problem. Singapore seems very aware of the importance of encouraging startups.

But while energetic government intervention may be able to make a port run efficiently, it can't coax startups into existence. A state that bans chewing gum has a long way to go before it could create a San Francisco.Do you need a San Francisco?

Might there not be an alternate route to innovation that goes through obedience and cooperation instead of individualism? Possibly, but I'd bet not. Most imaginative people seem to share a certain prickly independence, whenever and wherever they lived.

You see it in Diogenes telling Alexander to get out of his light and two thousand years later in Feynman breaking into safes at Los Alamos. [3] Imaginative people don't want to follow or lead. They're most productive when everyone gets to do what they want.Ironically, of all rich countries the US has lost the most civil liberties recently.

But I'm not too worried yet. I'm hoping once the present administration is out, the natural openness of American culture will reassert itself.4. American Universities Are Better.You need a great university to seed a silicon valley, and so far there are few outside the US.

I asked a handful of American computer science professors which universities in Europe were most admired, and they all basically said "Cambridge" followed by a long pause while they tried to think of others.

There don't seem to be many universities elsewhere that compare with the best in America, at least in technology.In some countries this is the result of a deliberate policy. The German and Dutch governments, perhaps from fear of elitism, try to ensure that all universities are roughly equal in quality.

The downside is that none are especially good. The best professors are spread out, instead of being concentrated as they are in the US. This probably makes them less productive, because they don't have good colleagues to inspire them.

It also means no one university will be good enough to act as a mecca, attracting talent from abroad and causing startups to form around it.The case of Germany is a strange one. The Germans invented the modern university, and up till the 1930s theirs were the best in the world.

Now they have none that stand out. As I was mulling this over, I found myself thinking: "I can understand why German universities declined in the 1930s, after they excluded Jews. But surely they should have bounced back by now." Then I realized: maybe not.

There are few Jews left in Germany and most Jews I know would not want to move there. And if you took any great American university and removed the Jews, you'd have some pretty big gaps. So maybe it would be a lost cause trying to create a silicon valley in Germany, because you couldn't establish the level of university you'd need as a seed.

[4]It's natural for US universities to compete with one another because so many are private. To reproduce the quality of American universities you probably also have to reproduce this. If universities are controlled by the central government, log-rolling will pull them all toward the mean: the new Institute of X will end up at the university in the district of a powerful politician, instead of where it should be.5.

You Can Fire People in America.I think one of the biggest obstacles to creating startups in Europe is the attitude toward employment. The famously rigid labor laws hurt every company, but startups especially, because startups have the least time to spare for bureaucratic hassles.The difficulty of firing people is a particular problem for startups because they have no redundancy.

Every person has to do their job well.But the problem is more than just that some startup might have a problem firing someone they needed to. Across industries and countries, there's a strong inverse correlation between performance and job security.

Actors and directors are fired at the end of each film, so they have to deliver every time. Junior professors are fired by default after a few years unless the university chooses to grant them tenure.

Professional athletes know they'll be pulled if they play badly for just a couple games. At the other end of the scale (at least in the US) are auto workers, New York City schoolteachers, and civil servants, who are all nearly impossible to fire.

The trend is so clear that you'd have to be willfully blind not to see it.Performance isn't everything, you say? Well, are auto workers, schoolteachers, and civil servants happier than actors, professors, and professional athletes?European public opinion will apparently tolerate people being fired in industries where they really care about performance.

Unfortunately the only industry they care enough about so far is soccer. But that is at least a precedent.6. In America Work Is Less Identified with Employment.The problem in more traditional places like Europe and Japan goes deeper than the employment laws.

More dangerous is the attitude they reflect: that an employee is a kind of servant, whom the employer has a duty to protect. It used to be that way in America too. In 1970 you were still supposed to get a job with a big company, for whom ideally you'd work your whole career.

In return the company would take care of you: they'd try not to fire you, cover your medical expenses, and support you in old age.Gradually employment has been shedding such paternalistic overtones and becoming simply an economic exchange.

But the importance of the new model is not just that it makes it easier for startups to grow. More important, I think, is that it it makes it easier for people to start startups.Even in the US most kids graduating from college still think they're supposed to get jobs, as if you couldn't be productive without being someone's employee.

But the less you identify work with employment, the easier it becomes to start a startup. When you see your career as a series of different types of work, instead of a lifetime's service to a single employer, there's less risk in starting your own company, because you're only replacing one segment instead of discarding the whole thing.The old ideas are so powerful that even the most successful startup founders have had to struggle against them.

A year after the founding of Apple, Steve Wozniak still hadn't quit HP. He still planned to work there for life. And when Jobs found someone to give Apple serious venture funding, on the condition that Woz quit, he initially refused, arguing that he'd designed both the Apple I and the Apple II while working at HP, and there was no reason he couldn't continue.7.

America Is Not Too Fussy.If there are any laws regulating businesses, you can assume larval startups will break most of them, because they don't know what the laws are and don't have time to find out.For example, many startups in America begin in places where it's not really legal to run a business.

Hewlett-Packard, Apple, and Google were all run out of garages. Many more startups, including ours, were initially run out of apartments. If the laws against such things were actually enforced, most startups wouldn't happen.That could be a problem in fussier countries.

If Hewlett and Packard tried running an electronics company out of their garage in Switzerland, the old lady next door would report them to the municipal authorities.But the worst problem in other countries is probably the effort required just to start a company.

A friend of mine started a company in Germany in the early 90s, and was shocked to discover, among many other regulations, that you needed $20,000 in capital to incorporate. That's one reason I'm not typing this on an Apfel laptop.

Jobs and Wozniak couldn't have come up with that kind of money in a company financed by selling a VW bus and an HP calculator. We couldn't have started Viaweb either. [5]Here's a tip for governments that want to encourage startups: read the stories of existing startups, and then try to simulate what would have happened in your country.

When you hit something that would have killed Apple, prune it off.Startups are marginal. They're started by the poor and the timid; they begin in marginal space and spare time; they're started by people who are supposed to be doing something else; and though businesses, their founders often know nothing about business.

Young startups are fragile. A society that trims its margins sharply will kill them all.8. America Has a Large Domestic Market.What sustains a startup in the beginning is the prospect of getting their initial product out.

The successful ones therefore make the first version as simple as possible. In the US they usually begin by making something just for the local market.This works in America, because the local market is 300 million people.

It wouldn't work so well in Sweden. In a small country, a startup has a harder task: they have to sell internationally from the start.The EU was designed partly to simulate a single, large domestic market.

The problem is that the inhabitants still speak many different languages. So a software startup in Sweden is still at a disadvantage relative to one in the US, because they have to deal with internationalization from the beginning.

It's significant that the most famous recent startup in Europe, Skype, worked on a problem that was intrinsically international.However, for better or worse it looks as if Europe will in a few decades speak a single language.

When I was a student in Italy in 1990, few Italians spoke English. Now all educated people seem to be expected to-- and Europeans do not like to seem uneducated. This is presumably a taboo subject, but if present trends continue, French and German will eventually go the way of Irish and Luxembourgish: they'll be spoken in homes and by eccentric nationalists.9.
America Has Venture Funding.Startups are easier to start in America because funding is easier to get. There are now a few VC firms outside the US, but startup funding doesn't only come from VC firms.

A more important source, because it's more personal and comes earlier in the process, is money from individual angel investors. Google might never have got to the point where they could raise millions from VC funds if they hadn't first raised a hundred thousand from Andy Bechtolsheim.

And he could help them because he was one of the founders of Sun. This pattern is repeated constantly in startup hubs. It's this pattern that makes them startup hubs.The good news is, all you have to do to get the process rolling is get those first few startups successfully launched.

If they stick around after they get rich, startup founders will almost automatically fund and encourage new startups.The bad news is that the cycle is slow. It probably takes five years, on average, before a startup founder can make angel investments.

And while governments might be able to set up local VC funds by supplying the money themselves and recruiting people from existing firms to run them, only organic growth can produce angel investors.Incidentally, America's private universities are one reason there's so much venture capital.

A lot of the money in VC funds comes from their endowments. So another advantage of private universities is that a good chunk of the country's wealth is managed by enlightened investors.10. America Has Dynamic Typing for Careers.Compared to other industrialized countries the US is disorganized about routing people into careers.

For example, in America people often don't decide to go to medical school till they've finished college. In Europe they generally decide in high school.The European approach reflects the old idea that each person has a single, definite occupation-- which is not far from the idea that each person has a natural "station" in life.

If this were true, the most efficient plan would be to discover each person's station as early as possible, so they could receive the training appropriate to it.In the US things are more haphazard. But that turns out to be an advantage as an economy gets more liquid, just as dynamic typing turns out to work better than static for ill-defined problems.

This is particularly true with startups. "Startup founder" is not the sort of career a high school student would choose. If you ask at that age, people will choose conservatively. They'll choose well-understood occupations like engineer, or doctor, or lawyer.Startups are the kind of thing people don't plan, so you're more likely to get them in a society where it's ok to make career decisions on the fly.For example, in theory the purpose of a PhD program is to train you to do research.

But fortunately in the US this is another rule that isn't very strictly enforced. In the US most people in CS PhD programs are there simply because they wanted to learn more. They haven't decided what they'll do afterward.

So American grad schools spawn a lot of startups, because students don't feel they're failing if they don't go into research.Those worried about America's "competitiveness" often suggest spending more on public schools.

But perhaps America's lousy public schools have a hidden advantage. Because they're so bad, the kids adopt an attitude of waiting for college. I did; I knew I was learning so little that I wasn't even learning what the choices were, let alone which to choose.

This is demoralizing, but it does at least make you keep an open mind.Certainly if I had to choose between bad high schools and good universities, like the US, and good high schools and bad universities, like most other industrialized countries, I'd take the US system.

Better to make everyone feel like a late bloomer than a failed child prodigy.AttitudesThere's one item conspicuously missing from this list: American attitudes. Americans are said to be more entrepreneurial, and less afraid of risk.

But America has no monopoly on this. Indians and Chinese seem plenty entrepreneurial, perhaps more than Americans.Some say Europeans are less energetic, but I don't believe it. I think the problem with Europe is not that they lack balls, but that they lack examples.Even in the US, the most successful startup founders are often technical people who are quite timid, initially, about the idea of starting their own company.

Few are the sort of backslapping extroverts one thinks of as typically American. They can usually only summon up the activation energy to start a startup when they meet people who've done it and realize they could too.I think what holds back European hackers is simply that they don't meet so many people who've done it.

You see that variation even within the US. Stanford students are more entrepreneurial than Yale students, but not because of some difference in their characters; the Yale students just have fewer examples.I admit there seem to be different attitudes toward ambition in Europe and the US.

In the US it's ok to be overtly ambitious, and in most of Europe it's not. But this can't be an intrinsically European quality; previous generations of Europeans were as ambitious as Americans. What happened?

My hypothesis is that ambition was discredited by the terrible things ambitious people did in the first half of the twentieth century. Now swagger is out. (Even now the image of a very ambitious German presses a button or two, doesn't it?)It would be surprising if European attitudes weren't affected by the disasters of the twentieth century.

It takes a while to be optimistic after events like that. But ambition is human nature. Gradually it will re-emerge. [6]How To Do BetterI don't mean to suggest by this list that America is the perfect place for startups.

It's the best place so far, but the sample size is small, and "so far" is not very long. On historical time scales, what we have now is just a prototype.So let's look at Silicon Valley the way you'd look at a product made by a competitor.

What weaknesses could you exploit? How could you make something users would like better? The users in this case are those critical few thousand people you'd like to move to your silicon valley.To start with, Silicon Valley is too far from San Francisco.

Palo Alto, the original ground zero, is about thirty miles away, and the present center more like forty. So people who come to work in Silicon Valley face an unpleasant choice: either live in the boring sprawl of the valley proper, or live in San Francisco and endure an hour commute each way.The best thing would be if the silicon valley were not merely closer to the interesting city, but interesting itself.

And there is a lot of room for improvement here. Palo Alto is not so bad, but everything built since is the worst sort of strip development. You can measure how demoralizing it is by the number of people who will sacrifice two hours a day commuting rather than live there.Another area in which you could easily surpass Silicon Valley is public transportation.

There is a train running the length of it, and by American standards it's not bad. Which is to say that to Japanese or Europeans it would seem like something out of the third world.The kind of people you want to attract to your silicon valley like to get around by train, bicycle, and on foot.

So if you want to beat America, design a town that puts cars last. It will be a while before any American city can bring itself to do that.Capital GainsThere are also a couple things you could do to beat America at the national level.

One would be to have lower capital gains taxes. It doesn't seem critical to have the lowest income taxes, because to take advantage of those, people have to move. [7] But if capital gains rates vary, you move assets, not yourself, so changes are reflected at market speeds.

The lower the rate, the cheaper it is to buy stock in growing companies as opposed to real estate, or bonds, or stocks bought for the dividends they pay.So if you want to encourage startups you should have a low rate on capital gains.

Politicians are caught between a rock and a hard place here, however: make the capital gains rate low and be accused of creating "tax breaks for the rich," or make it high and starve growing companies of investment capital.

As Galbraith said, politics is a matter of choosing between the unpalatable and the disastrous. A lot of governments experimented with the disastrous in the twentieth century; now the trend seems to be toward the merely unpalatable.Oddly enough, the leaders now are European countries like Belgium, which has a capital gains tax rate of zero.ImmigrationThe other place you could beat the US would be with smarter immigration policy.

There are huge gains to be made here. Silicon valleys are made of people, remember.Like a company whose software runs on Windows, those in the current Silicon Valley are all too aware of the shortcomings of the INS, but there's little they can do about it.

They're hostages of the platform.America's immigration system has never been well run, and since 2001 there has been an additional admixture of paranoia. What fraction of the smart people who want to come to America can even get in?

I doubt even half. Which means if you made a competing technology hub that let in all smart people, you'd immediately get more than half the world's top talent, for free.US immigration policy is particularly ill-suited to startups, because it reflects a model of work from the 1970s.

It assumes good technical people have college degrees, and that work means working for a big company.If you don't have a college degree you can't get an H1B visa, the type usually issued to programmers.

But a test that excludes Steve Jobs, Bill Gates, and Michael Dell can't be a good one. Plus you can't get a visa for working on your own company, only for working as an employee of someone else's. And if you want to apply for citizenship you daren't work for a startup at all, because if your sponsor goes out of business, you have to start over.American immigration policy keeps out most smart people, and channels the rest into unproductive jobs.

It would be easy to do better. Imagine if, instead, you treated immigration like recruiting-- if you made a conscious effort to seek out the smartest people and get them to come to your country.A country that got immigration right would have a huge advantage.

At this point you could become a mecca for smart people simply by having an immigration system that let them in.A Good VectorIf you look at the kinds of things you have to do to create an environment where startups condense, none are great sacrifices.

Great universities? Livable towns? Civil liberties? Flexible employment laws? Immigration policies that let in smart people? Tax laws that encourage growth? It's not as if you have to risk destroying your country to get a silicon valley; these are all good things in their own right.And then of course there's the question, can you afford not to?

I can imagine a future in which the default choice of ambitious young people is to start their own company rather than work for someone else's. I'm not sure that will happen, but it's where the trend points now.

And if that is the future, places that don't have startups will be a whole step behind, like those that missed the Industrial Revolution.Notes[1] On the verge of the Industrial Revolution, England was already the richest country in the world.

As far as such things can be compared, per capita income in England in 1750 was higher than India's in 1960.Deane, Phyllis, The First Industrial Revolution, Cambridge University Press, 1965.[2] This has already happened once in China, during the Ming Dynasty, when the country turned its back on industrialization at the command of the court.

One of Europe's advantages was that it had no government powerful enough to do that.[3] Of course, Feynman and Diogenes were from adjacent traditions, but Confucius, though more polite, was no more willing to be told what to think.[4] For similar reasons it might be a lost cause to try to establish a silicon valley in Israel.

Instead of no Jews moving there, only Jews would move there, and I don't think you could build a silicon valley out of just Jews any more than you could out of just Japanese.(This is not a remark about the qualities of these groups, just their sizes.

Japanese are only about 2% of the world population, and Jews about .2%.)[5] According to the World Bank, the initial capital requirement for German companies is 47.6% of the per capita income. Doh.World Bank, Doing Business in 2006, http://doingbusiness.org[6] For most of the twentieth century, Europeans looked back on the summer of 1914 as if they'd been living in a dream world.

It seems more accurate (or at least, as accurate) to call the years after 1914 a nightmare than to call those before a dream. A lot of the optimism Europeans consider distinctly American is simply what they too were feeling in 1914.[7] The point where things start to go wrong seems to be about 50%.

Above that people get serious about tax avoidance. The reason is that the payoff for avoiding tax grows hyperexponentially (x/1-x for 0 < x < 1). If your income tax rate is 10%, moving to Monaco would only give you 11% more income, which wouldn't even cover the extra cost.

If it's 90%, you'd get ten times as much income. And at 98%, as it was briefly in Britain in the 70s, moving to Monaco would give you fifty times as much income. It seems quite likely that European governments of the 70s never drew this curve.Thanks to Trevor Blackwell, Matthias Felleisen, Jessica Livingston, Robert Morris, Neil Rimer, Hugues Steinier, Brad Templeton, Fred Wilson, and Stephen Wolfram for reading drafts of this, and to Ed Dumbill for inviting me to speak.French TranslationRussian TranslationJapanese TranslationArabic Translation

paragraphs.original: Can it get you the designers, though? Can imagination flourish where people can't criticize the government? Imagination means having odd ideas, and it's hard to have odd ideas about technology without also having odd ideas about politics.
paragraphs.translated: 不过，这能为你找到设计师吗？在人们不能批评政府的地方，想象力能蓬勃发展吗？想象力意味着有奇特的想法，而没有关于政治的奇特想法，就很难有关于技术的奇特想法。

paragraphs.original: And in any case, many technical ideas do have political implications. So if you squash dissent, the back pressure will propagate into technical fields. [2]Singapore would face a similar problem. Singapore seems very aware of the importance of encouraging startups.
paragraphs.translated: 而且，许多技术理念确实具有政治影响。因此，如果你压制异议，这种反作用力会蔓延到技术领域。[2]新加坡也会面临类似的问题。新加坡似乎非常清楚鼓励创业公司的重要性。

paragraphs.original: But while energetic government intervention may be able to make a port run efficiently, it can't coax startups into existence. A state that bans chewing gum has a long way to go before it could create a San Francisco.Do you need a San Francisco?
paragraphs.translated: 但是，虽然政府的积极干预可能使港口高效运作，但它无法催生创业公司的诞生。一个禁止嚼口香糖的国家，在能够创造出一个旧金山之前，还有很长的路要走。你需要一个旧金山吗？

paragraphs.original: Might there not be an alternate route to innovation that goes through obedience and cooperation instead of individualism? Possibly, but I'd bet not. Most imaginative people seem to share a certain prickly independence, whenever and wherever they lived.
paragraphs.translated: 是否可能存在一条通过服从和合作而不是个人主义来实现创新的替代路径？可能有，但我认为不大可能。大多数富有想象力的人似乎都具有一种棘手的独立性，无论他们生活在何时何地。

paragraphs.original: You see it in Diogenes telling Alexander to get out of his light and two thousand years later in Feynman breaking into safes at Los Alamos. [3] Imaginative people don't want to follow or lead. They're most productive when everyone gets to do what they want.Ironically, of all rich countries the US has lost the most civil liberties recently.
paragraphs.translated: 你可以在第欧根尼让亚历山大不要挡住他的阳光，以及两千年后费曼在洛斯阿拉莫斯破解保险箱的故事中看到这一点。[3] 富有想象力的人既不想追随也不想领导。当每个人都能做自己想做的事情时，他们最富有创造力。讽刺的是，在所有富裕国家中，美国最近失去了最多的公民自由。

paragraphs.original: But I'm not too worried yet. I'm hoping once the present administration is out, the natural openness of American culture will reassert itself.4. American Universities Are Better.You need a great university to seed a silicon valley, and so far there are few outside the US.
paragraphs.translated: 但我不太担心。我希望一旦现任政府下台，美国文化的天然开放性会重新显现。4. 美国的大学更好。要孕育一个硅谷，你需要一流的大学，而到目前为止，这样的大学在美国以外的地方还很少见。

paragraphs.original: I asked a handful of American computer science professors which universities in Europe were most admired, and they all basically said "Cambridge" followed by a long pause while they tried to think of others.
paragraphs.translated: 我询问了一些美国计算机科学教授，哪些欧洲大学最受推崇，他们几乎都说出了“剑桥”，然后就是一阵长时间的停顿，他们在努力思考其他可能的大学。

paragraphs.original: There don't seem to be many universities elsewhere that compare with the best in America, at least in technology.In some countries this is the result of a deliberate policy. The German and Dutch governments, perhaps from fear of elitism, try to ensure that all universities are roughly equal in quality.
paragraphs.translated: 似乎没有多少其他国家的大学能与美国最好的大学相提并论，至少在技术方面是如此。在一些国家，这是有意为之的政策结果。德国和荷兰政府或许出于对精英主义的担忧，努力确保所有大学在质量上大致相当。

paragraphs.original: The downside is that none are especially good. The best professors are spread out, instead of being concentrated as they are in the US. This probably makes them less productive, because they don't have good colleagues to inspire them.
paragraphs.translated: 缺点是这些学校没有一所特别出色。最好的教授分布得很分散，而不是像在美国那样集中。这可能使他们效率更低，因为他们没有优秀的同事来激发他们的灵感。

paragraphs.original: It also means no one university will be good enough to act as a mecca, attracting talent from abroad and causing startups to form around it.The case of Germany is a strange one. The Germans invented the modern university, and up till the 1930s theirs were the best in the world.
paragraphs.translated: 这也意味着没有一所大学能够足够优秀，成为吸引海外人才的圣地，并在其周围形成创业公司。德国的情况很特殊。德国人发明了现代大学，直到20世纪30年代，他们的大学都是世界上最好的。

paragraphs.original: Now they have none that stand out. As I was mulling this over, I found myself thinking: "I can understand why German universities declined in the 1930s, after they excluded Jews. But surely they should have bounced back by now." Then I realized: maybe not.
paragraphs.translated: 现在它们中没有一个特别突出。当我思考这个问题时，我心中想到：“我可以理解为什么德国大学在1930年代排斥犹太人后开始衰落。但它们肯定应该已经恢复了。” 然后我意识到：也许并非如此。

paragraphs.original: There are few Jews left in Germany and most Jews I know would not want to move there. And if you took any great American university and removed the Jews, you'd have some pretty big gaps. So maybe it would be a lost cause trying to create a silicon valley in Germany, because you couldn't establish the level of university you'd need as a seed.
paragraphs.translated: 德国已经没有多少犹太人了，而我认识的大多数犹太人都不愿意搬到那里。如果你把任何一个顶尖的美国大学里的犹太人都移除，你会发现在这些大学里会留下一些相当大的空白。所以，或许在德国尝试创建一个硅谷会是一个徒劳的努力，因为你无法建立起作为种子的高等教育水平。

paragraphs.original: [4]It's natural for US universities to compete with one another because so many are private. To reproduce the quality of American universities you probably also have to reproduce this. If universities are controlled by the central government, log-rolling will pull them all toward the mean: the new Institute of X will end up at the university in the district of a powerful politician, instead of where it should be.5.
paragraphs.translated: 美国的大学相互竞争是很自然的，因为其中有很大一部分是私立的。要复制美国大学的高质量，可能也需要复制这一点。如果大学由中央政府控制，那么利益交换将会使所有大学趋向平均：新的X研究所最终会设在某个有权势的政治家所在选区的大学，而不是应该设立的地方。

paragraphs.original: You Can Fire People in America.I think one of the biggest obstacles to creating startups in Europe is the attitude toward employment. The famously rigid labor laws hurt every company, but startups especially, because startups have the least time to spare for bureaucratic hassles.The difficulty of firing people is a particular problem for startups because they have no redundancy.
paragraphs.translated: 在美国，你可以解雇员工。我认为，阻碍欧洲创建初创企业的一个最大障碍是对待就业的态度。著名的严格劳动法对每家公司都有害，但对初创企业尤其如此，因为初创企业最没有时间去应付官僚主义的麻烦。解雇员工的困难对初创企业来说尤其成问题，因为它们没有冗员。

paragraphs.original: Every person has to do their job well.But the problem is more than just that some startup might have a problem firing someone they needed to. Across industries and countries, there's a strong inverse correlation between performance and job security.
paragraphs.translated: 每个人都要做好自己的工作。但问题不仅仅是某些初创公司可能难以解雇他们需要解雇的人。在各行各业和各国之间，绩效和工作保障之间存在着强烈的负相关关系。

paragraphs.original: Actors and directors are fired at the end of each film, so they have to deliver every time. Junior professors are fired by default after a few years unless the university chooses to grant them tenure.
paragraphs.translated: 演员和导演在每部电影结束后都会被解雇，因此他们每次都需要全力以赴。初级教授默认在几年后会被解雇，除非大学决定授予他们终身教职。

paragraphs.original: Professional athletes know they'll be pulled if they play badly for just a couple games. At the other end of the scale (at least in the US) are auto workers, New York City schoolteachers, and civil servants, who are all nearly impossible to fire.
paragraphs.translated: 职业运动员知道，如果他们在几场比赛中表现不佳，就会被替换。而在另一端（至少在美国）是汽车工人、纽约市的教师和公务员，他们几乎是不可能被解雇的。

paragraphs.original: The trend is so clear that you'd have to be willfully blind not to see it.Performance isn't everything, you say? Well, are auto workers, schoolteachers, and civil servants happier than actors, professors, and professional athletes?European public opinion will apparently tolerate people being fired in industries where they really care about performance.
paragraphs.translated: 这种趋势如此明显，你要是看不见，那一定是故意视而不见。你说性能不是一切？那么，汽车工人、学校教师和公务员真的比演员、教授和职业运动员更幸福吗？显然，欧洲公众舆论在那些真正重视绩效的行业中，是可以容忍解雇员工的。

paragraphs.original: Unfortunately the only industry they care enough about so far is soccer. But that is at least a precedent.6. In America Work Is Less Identified with Employment.The problem in more traditional places like Europe and Japan goes deeper than the employment laws.
paragraphs.translated: 不幸的是，到目前为止他们唯一关心的行业是足球。但至少这是一个先例。在美国，工作与雇佣的关系不那么紧密。在欧洲和日本等更为传统的地区，问题不仅仅在于就业法律。

paragraphs.original: More dangerous is the attitude they reflect: that an employee is a kind of servant, whom the employer has a duty to protect. It used to be that way in America too. In 1970 you were still supposed to get a job with a big company, for whom ideally you'd work your whole career.
paragraphs.translated: 更危险的是这种态度所反映的观点：员工是一种仆人，雇主有责任保护他们。在美国，过去也曾是这样。1970年时，人们还普遍认为应该在一家大公司里找到工作，并且理想情况下会在这家公司工作一辈子。

paragraphs.original: In return the company would take care of you: they'd try not to fire you, cover your medical expenses, and support you in old age.Gradually employment has been shedding such paternalistic overtones and becoming simply an economic exchange.
paragraphs.translated: 作为回报，公司会照顾你：他们会尽量不解雇你，承担你的医疗费用，并在你年老时支持你。渐渐地，就业已经摆脱了这种家长式的色彩，变成了一种纯粹的经济交换。

paragraphs.original: But the importance of the new model is not just that it makes it easier for startups to grow. More important, I think, is that it it makes it easier for people to start startups.Even in the US most kids graduating from college still think they're supposed to get jobs, as if you couldn't be productive without being someone's employee.
paragraphs.translated: 但新模型的重要之处不仅在于它让初创企业更容易成长。更为重要的是，它让人们更容易开始创办初创企业。即使在美国，大多数即将从大学毕业的学生仍然认为他们应该去找工作，好像不成为别人的雇员就无法有所作为。

paragraphs.original: But the less you identify work with employment, the easier it becomes to start a startup. When you see your career as a series of different types of work, instead of a lifetime's service to a single employer, there's less risk in starting your own company, because you're only replacing one segment instead of discarding the whole thing.The old ideas are so powerful that even the most successful startup founders have had to struggle against them.
paragraphs.translated: 但是，你越不把工作等同于就业，开始创业就越容易。当你将职业生涯视为一系列不同类型的工作，而不是对单一雇主终身服务时，创业的风险就会降低，因为你只是替换了一个部分，而不是抛弃整个职业生涯。旧观念如此根深蒂固，以至于即使是最成功的创业创始人也不得不与之抗争。

paragraphs.original: A year after the founding of Apple, Steve Wozniak still hadn't quit HP. He still planned to work there for life. And when Jobs found someone to give Apple serious venture funding, on the condition that Woz quit, he initially refused, arguing that he'd designed both the Apple I and the Apple II while working at HP, and there was no reason he couldn't continue.7.
paragraphs.translated: 苹果公司成立一年后，史蒂夫·沃兹尼亚克仍然没有离开惠普。他依然计划在那里工作一辈子。当乔布斯找到愿意给苹果提供重要风险投资的人时，条件是沃兹必须辞职，他最初拒绝了，理由是他设计了苹果I和苹果II时都在惠普工作，没有理由不能继续这样做。

paragraphs.original: America Is Not Too Fussy.If there are any laws regulating businesses, you can assume larval startups will break most of them, because they don't know what the laws are and don't have time to find out.For example, many startups in America begin in places where it's not really legal to run a business.
paragraphs.translated: 美国在这方面并不太挑剔。如果有任何法规监管企业，你可以假设初创公司会违反其中的大部分，因为他们不知道这些法规是什么，也没有时间去了解。例如，许多美国的初创公司都是在不适合经营业务的地方开始的。

paragraphs.original: Hewlett-Packard, Apple, and Google were all run out of garages. Many more startups, including ours, were initially run out of apartments. If the laws against such things were actually enforced, most startups wouldn't happen.That could be a problem in fussier countries.
paragraphs.translated: 惠普、苹果和谷歌最初都是在车库里运营的。还有许多初创公司，包括我们自己的，最初是在公寓里运营的。如果这些法律规定真的被严格执行，大多数初创公司就不会存在了。这在那些更讲究的国家可能是个问题。

paragraphs.original: If Hewlett and Packard tried running an electronics company out of their garage in Switzerland, the old lady next door would report them to the municipal authorities.But the worst problem in other countries is probably the effort required just to start a company.
paragraphs.translated: 如果休利特和帕卡德试图在瑞士的车库里经营一家电子公司，隔壁的老太太会把他们举报给市政当局。但在其他国家，最大的问题可能只是创办一家公司所需的努力。

paragraphs.original: A friend of mine started a company in Germany in the early 90s, and was shocked to discover, among many other regulations, that you needed $20,000 in capital to incorporate. That's one reason I'm not typing this on an Apfel laptop.
paragraphs.translated: 我的一位朋友在90年代初在德国创办了一家公司，令他震惊的是，除了许多其他规定之外，他还发现需要20,000美元的资本才能注册公司。这就是我为什么没有在一台Apfel笔记本电脑上打字的原因之一。

paragraphs.original: Jobs and Wozniak couldn't have come up with that kind of money in a company financed by selling a VW bus and an HP calculator. We couldn't have started Viaweb either. [5]Here's a tip for governments that want to encourage startups: read the stories of existing startups, and then try to simulate what would have happened in your country.
paragraphs.translated: 乔布斯和沃兹尼亚克不可能通过出售一辆大众公交车和一台惠普计算器来筹集到那样的资金。我们也不可能启动Viaweb。[5]这里有一个建议给希望鼓励创业的政府：阅读现有的创业故事，然后尝试模拟如果这些故事发生在你的国家会怎样。

paragraphs.original: When you hit something that would have killed Apple, prune it off.Startups are marginal. They're started by the poor and the timid; they begin in marginal space and spare time; they're started by people who are supposed to be doing something else; and though businesses, their founders often know nothing about business.
paragraphs.translated: 当你遇到可能置苹果公司于死地的问题时，将其剔除。创业公司是边缘的。它们由穷人和胆小的人创立；它们始于边缘的空间和空闲时间；它们的创立者本应做其他事情；尽管是企业，但其创始人往往对企业一无所知。

paragraphs.original: Young startups are fragile. A society that trims its margins sharply will kill them all.8. America Has a Large Domestic Market.What sustains a startup in the beginning is the prospect of getting their initial product out.
paragraphs.translated: 年轻的初创企业是脆弱的。一个大幅削减边缘的社会将扼杀它们。美国拥有庞大的国内市场。支撑初创企业在初期生存下去的是推出其初始产品的前景。

paragraphs.original: The successful ones therefore make the first version as simple as possible. In the US they usually begin by making something just for the local market.This works in America, because the local market is 300 million people.
paragraphs.translated: 因此，成功的人会让第一个版本尽可能简单。在美国，他们通常首先为本地市场制作产品。这在美国行得通，因为本地市场有3亿人口。

paragraphs.original: It wouldn't work so well in Sweden. In a small country, a startup has a harder task: they have to sell internationally from the start.The EU was designed partly to simulate a single, large domestic market.
paragraphs.translated: 在瑞典就不会那么有效了。在一个小国，初创公司面临着更艰巨的任务：他们从一开始就不得不向国际市场销售。欧盟的部分设计目的是模拟一个单一的大市场。

paragraphs.original: The problem is that the inhabitants still speak many different languages. So a software startup in Sweden is still at a disadvantage relative to one in the US, because they have to deal with internationalization from the beginning.
paragraphs.translated: 问题在于居民仍然使用许多不同的语言。因此，瑞典的一家软件初创公司在一开始就不得不处理国际化问题，这使得它相对于美国的初创公司处于劣势。

paragraphs.original: It's significant that the most famous recent startup in Europe, Skype, worked on a problem that was intrinsically international.However, for better or worse it looks as if Europe will in a few decades speak a single language.
paragraphs.translated: 最近欧洲最著名的创业公司Skype解决了本质上是国际性的问题，这一点非常重要。然而，不管好与坏，看起来再过几十年，整个欧洲将使用同一种语言。

paragraphs.original: When I was a student in Italy in 1990, few Italians spoke English. Now all educated people seem to be expected to-- and Europeans do not like to seem uneducated. This is presumably a taboo subject, but if present trends continue, French and German will eventually go the way of Irish and Luxembourgish: they'll be spoken in homes and by eccentric nationalists.9.
paragraphs.translated: 1990年我在意大利求学时，很少有意大利人说英语。现在，所有受过教育的人都似乎被期望会说——而欧洲人不喜欢显得没受过教育。这大概是一个禁忌话题，但如果当前趋势持续下去，法语和德语最终可能会像爱尔兰语和卢森堡语一样：只在家庭中和一些特立独行的民族主义者中使用。

paragraphs.original: America Has Venture Funding.Startups are easier to start in America because funding is easier to get. There are now a few VC firms outside the US, but startup funding doesn't only come from VC firms.
paragraphs.translated: 美国有风险投资。在美国，创业公司更容易起步，因为资金更容易获得。虽然现在美国以外也有一些风投公司，但创业资金并不只来自风投公司。

paragraphs.original: A more important source, because it's more personal and comes earlier in the process, is money from individual angel investors. Google might never have got to the point where they could raise millions from VC funds if they hadn't first raised a hundred thousand from Andy Bechtolsheim.
paragraphs.translated: 一个更重要的资金来源，因为它更具个人性且出现在过程的早期，是个别天使投资者的资金。如果没有先从安迪·贝克托舍姆那里筹集到十几万美元，谷歌可能永远不会达到能够从风险投资基金筹集数百万资金的阶段。

paragraphs.original: And he could help them because he was one of the founders of Sun. This pattern is repeated constantly in startup hubs. It's this pattern that makes them startup hubs.The good news is, all you have to do to get the process rolling is get those first few startups successfully launched.
paragraphs.translated: 他能够帮助他们，因为他曾是Sun公司的创始人之一。这个模式在创业中心不断重复。正是这种模式使它们成为创业中心。好消息是，你只需要成功启动最初那几家公司，就能启动这一进程。

paragraphs.original: If they stick around after they get rich, startup founders will almost automatically fund and encourage new startups.The bad news is that the cycle is slow. It probably takes five years, on average, before a startup founder can make angel investments.
paragraphs.translated: 如果创业公司在致富后继续留在行业里，创始人几乎会自然而然地资助和鼓励新的创业公司。但坏消息是，这个循环很慢。平均而言，一个创业公司的创始人可能需要五年时间才能开始进行天使投资。

paragraphs.original: And while governments might be able to set up local VC funds by supplying the money themselves and recruiting people from existing firms to run them, only organic growth can produce angel investors.Incidentally, America's private universities are one reason there's so much venture capital.
paragraphs.translated: 而虽然政府可以通过自己提供资金并从现有公司招募人员来管理来设立本地风投基金，但只有自然增长才能产生天使投资者。顺便说一下，美国的私立大学是风险资本如此丰富的一个原因。

paragraphs.original: A lot of the money in VC funds comes from their endowments. So another advantage of private universities is that a good chunk of the country's wealth is managed by enlightened investors.10. America Has Dynamic Typing for Careers.Compared to other industrialized countries the US is disorganized about routing people into careers.
paragraphs.translated: 风投基金中的大量资金来源于它们的捐赠基金。因此，私立大学的另一个优势是，国家财富中相当可观的一部分是由具有远见的投资者管理的。10. 美国的职业路径具有动态性。与其它工业化国家相比，美国在引导人们进入职业路径方面显得较为松散。

paragraphs.original: For example, in America people often don't decide to go to medical school till they've finished college. In Europe they generally decide in high school.The European approach reflects the old idea that each person has a single, definite occupation-- which is not far from the idea that each person has a natural "station" in life.
paragraphs.translated: 例如，在美国，人们通常要到大学毕业后才会决定上医学院。而在欧洲，人们通常在高中时就决定了。欧洲的做法反映了旧观念，即每个人都有一个单一且确定的职业——这与每个人都有天生的“社会地位”的观念相去不远。

paragraphs.original: If this were true, the most efficient plan would be to discover each person's station as early as possible, so they could receive the training appropriate to it.In the US things are more haphazard. But that turns out to be an advantage as an economy gets more liquid, just as dynamic typing turns out to work better than static for ill-defined problems.
paragraphs.translated: 如果这是真的，最有效的计划将是尽早发现每个人的位置，以便他们能够接受相应的培训。在美国，事情则更加随意。但事实证明，当经济变得更加流动时，这种随意性反而成为一种优势，就像动态类型在处理未明确定义的问题时比静态类型更有效一样。

paragraphs.original: This is particularly true with startups. "Startup founder" is not the sort of career a high school student would choose. If you ask at that age, people will choose conservatively. They'll choose well-understood occupations like engineer, or doctor, or lawyer.Startups are the kind of thing people don't plan, so you're more likely to get them in a society where it's ok to make career decisions on the fly.For example, in theory the purpose of a PhD program is to train you to do research.
paragraphs.translated: 这在初创企业中尤其如此。“初创企业创始人”不是高中生会选择的职业。在这个年龄问他们，人们会选择保守的职业。他们会挑选像工程师、医生或律师这样为人熟知的职业。初创企业是人们不会刻意规划的事情，因此在一个可以随意做出职业选择的社会中，你更有可能遇到初创企业。例如，理论上博士项目的目的在于培养你进行研究的能力。

paragraphs.original: But fortunately in the US this is another rule that isn't very strictly enforced. In the US most people in CS PhD programs are there simply because they wanted to learn more. They haven't decided what they'll do afterward.
paragraphs.translated: 但幸运的是，在美国，这条规定并不过于严格。在美国，大多数计算机科学博士项目的学生只是因为想学习更多而在这里，他们还没有决定毕业后要做什么。

paragraphs.original: So American grad schools spawn a lot of startups, because students don't feel they're failing if they don't go into research.Those worried about America's "competitiveness" often suggest spending more on public schools.
paragraphs.translated: 因此，美国的研究生院孵化了大量创业公司，因为学生们并不会因为没有进入研究领域而感到失败。那些担心美国“竞争力”的人经常建议增加对公立学校的投入。

paragraphs.original: But perhaps America's lousy public schools have a hidden advantage. Because they're so bad, the kids adopt an attitude of waiting for college. I did; I knew I was learning so little that I wasn't even learning what the choices were, let alone which to choose.
paragraphs.translated: 但也许美国糟糕的公立学校有一个隐藏的优势。因为它们太差了，孩子们养成了等待上大学的态度。我就这样；我知道我学得如此之少，以至于我甚至都不知道有哪些选择，更不用说选择哪个了。

paragraphs.original: This is demoralizing, but it does at least make you keep an open mind.Certainly if I had to choose between bad high schools and good universities, like the US, and good high schools and bad universities, like most other industrialized countries, I'd take the US system.
paragraphs.translated: 这令人沮丧，但至少它让你保持开放的心态。如果我必须在像美国那样的糟糕高中和优质大学，以及像大多数其他工业化国家那样的优质高中和糟糕大学之间做出选择，我会选择美国的教育体系。

paragraphs.original: Better to make everyone feel like a late bloomer than a failed child prodigy.AttitudesThere's one item conspicuously missing from this list: American attitudes. Americans are said to be more entrepreneurial, and less afraid of risk.
paragraphs.translated: 最好让每个人觉得自己是大器晚成，而不是失败的神童。态度：这个列表中有一个明显缺失的项目：美国人的态度。据说美国人更加具有创业精神，且不太害怕冒险。

paragraphs.original: But America has no monopoly on this. Indians and Chinese seem plenty entrepreneurial, perhaps more than Americans.Some say Europeans are less energetic, but I don't believe it. I think the problem with Europe is not that they lack balls, but that they lack examples.Even in the US, the most successful startup founders are often technical people who are quite timid, initially, about the idea of starting their own company.
paragraphs.translated: 但美国在这方面并不是独一无二的。印度人和中国人似乎也颇具创业精神，甚至可能超过美国人。有人说欧洲人缺乏活力，但我并不认同。我认为欧洲的问题不在于他们缺乏勇气，而是缺乏榜样。即使在美国，最成功的初创企业创始人也往往是技术出身的人，他们最初对创办自己的公司这个想法往往是相当胆怯的。

paragraphs.original: Few are the sort of backslapping extroverts one thinks of as typically American. They can usually only summon up the activation energy to start a startup when they meet people who've done it and realize they could too.I think what holds back European hackers is simply that they don't meet so many people who've done it.
paragraphs.translated: 很少有人是那种典型的美国式的拍肩握手型外向者。他们通常只有在遇到那些已经创业成功的人，并意识到自己也能做到时，才能激发起创业的活力。我认为阻碍欧洲黑客创业的，仅仅是因为他们没有遇到那么多已经成功创业的人。

paragraphs.original: You see that variation even within the US. Stanford students are more entrepreneurial than Yale students, but not because of some difference in their characters; the Yale students just have fewer examples.I admit there seem to be different attitudes toward ambition in Europe and the US.
paragraphs.translated: 你在美国国内也能看到这种差异。斯坦福的学生比耶鲁的学生更具有创业精神，但这并不是因为他们的性格有什么不同；耶鲁的学生只是拥有的榜样较少。我承认，在欧洲和美国，人们对雄心的态度似乎存在差异。

paragraphs.original: In the US it's ok to be overtly ambitious, and in most of Europe it's not. But this can't be an intrinsically European quality; previous generations of Europeans were as ambitious as Americans. What happened?
paragraphs.translated: 在美国，公开表现出雄心壮志是可以接受的，而在欧洲大部分地区则不然。但这不可能是欧洲人固有的特质；以前的欧洲人和美国人一样有雄心。那么，发生了什么？

paragraphs.original: My hypothesis is that ambition was discredited by the terrible things ambitious people did in the first half of the twentieth century. Now swagger is out. (Even now the image of a very ambitious German presses a button or two, doesn't it?)It would be surprising if European attitudes weren't affected by the disasters of the twentieth century.
paragraphs.translated: 我的假设是，20世纪上半叶有野心的人所做的一些可怕的事情使雄心壮志蒙上了污名。现在，自负已经失宠。（即使现在，一个非常有野心的德国人的形象也会触动一些人的神经，不是吗？）如果20世纪的灾难没有影响欧洲人的态度，那才会令人惊讶。

paragraphs.original: It takes a while to be optimistic after events like that. But ambition is human nature. Gradually it will re-emerge. [6]How To Do BetterI don't mean to suggest by this list that America is the perfect place for startups.
paragraphs.translated: 这样的事件之后，要恢复乐观需要一段时间。但雄心壮志是人的天性，渐渐地它会重新浮现。[6]如何做得更好我列出这些并不是想说美国是创业公司的完美之地。

paragraphs.original: It's the best place so far, but the sample size is small, and "so far" is not very long. On historical time scales, what we have now is just a prototype.So let's look at Silicon Valley the way you'd look at a product made by a competitor.
paragraphs.translated: 这是迄今为止最好的地方，但样本量很小，而“迄今为止”也并不长。从历史的时间尺度来看，我们现在所拥有的只是一个原型。因此，让我们像看待竞争对手的产品一样来看待硅谷。

paragraphs.original: What weaknesses could you exploit? How could you make something users would like better? The users in this case are those critical few thousand people you'd like to move to your silicon valley.To start with, Silicon Valley is too far from San Francisco.
paragraphs.translated: 你能利用哪些弱点？你如何使产品更受用户喜爱？这里的用户是指你希望吸引到硅谷的那几千个关键人物。首先，硅谷距离旧金山太远。

paragraphs.original: Palo Alto, the original ground zero, is about thirty miles away, and the present center more like forty. So people who come to work in Silicon Valley face an unpleasant choice: either live in the boring sprawl of the valley proper, or live in San Francisco and endure an hour commute each way.The best thing would be if the silicon valley were not merely closer to the interesting city, but interesting itself.
paragraphs.translated: 帕洛阿尔托，最初的零点，距离这里大约三十英里，而现在的中心则更远，大约四十英里。因此，来这里工作的硅谷人们面临着一个不愉快的选择：要么住在乏味的硅谷郊区，要么住在旧金山，忍受每天一小时的通勤。最好的情况是，如果硅谷不仅更接近这座有趣的城市，而且自身也变得有趣。

paragraphs.original: And there is a lot of room for improvement here. Palo Alto is not so bad, but everything built since is the worst sort of strip development. You can measure how demoralizing it is by the number of people who will sacrifice two hours a day commuting rather than live there.Another area in which you could easily surpass Silicon Valley is public transportation.
paragraphs.translated: 这里有很大的改进空间。帕洛阿尔托还不错，但自那以后建设的一切都是最糟糕的带状开发区。你可以通过每天愿意牺牲两小时通勤时间也不愿住在那里的人数来衡量这种沮丧感。另一个可以轻松超越硅谷的领域是公共交通。

paragraphs.original: There is a train running the length of it, and by American standards it's not bad. Which is to say that to Japanese or Europeans it would seem like something out of the third world.The kind of people you want to attract to your silicon valley like to get around by train, bicycle, and on foot.
paragraphs.translated: 有一列火车贯穿全程，按照美国的标准来说还不错。也就是说，对于日本人或欧洲人来说，这可能看起来像是第三世界的东西。你想要吸引到你的硅谷的那种人，喜欢乘坐火车、骑自行车或步行出行。

paragraphs.original: So if you want to beat America, design a town that puts cars last. It will be a while before any American city can bring itself to do that.Capital GainsThere are also a couple things you could do to beat America at the national level.
paragraphs.translated: 所以，如果你想超越美国，就设计一个以汽车为次要的城镇。美国的任何城市要想做到这一点还需要一段时间。资本利得方面，也有几件事你可以做来在国家层面上超越美国。

paragraphs.original: One would be to have lower capital gains taxes. It doesn't seem critical to have the lowest income taxes, because to take advantage of those, people have to move. [7] But if capital gains rates vary, you move assets, not yourself, so changes are reflected at market speeds.
paragraphs.translated: 一种方法是降低资本利得税。似乎并不关键需要拥有最低的所得税，因为要享受这些优惠，人们必须搬迁。[7] 但若资本利得税率有所不同，人们转移的是资产而非自身，因此变化会以市场速度反映出来。

paragraphs.original: The lower the rate, the cheaper it is to buy stock in growing companies as opposed to real estate, or bonds, or stocks bought for the dividends they pay.So if you want to encourage startups you should have a low rate on capital gains.
paragraphs.translated: 利率越低，购买成长型公司的股票就越便宜，相对于房地产、债券或为了分红而购买的股票而言。因此，如果你想鼓励初创企业，就应该对资本利得征收较低的税率。

paragraphs.original: Politicians are caught between a rock and a hard place here, however: make the capital gains rate low and be accused of creating "tax breaks for the rich," or make it high and starve growing companies of investment capital.
paragraphs.translated: 然而，政治家们在此进退两难：如果将资本利得税率定得较低，就会被指责为给富人提供“税收优惠”；如果定得较高，则会导致成长中的公司缺乏投资资金。

paragraphs.original: As Galbraith said, politics is a matter of choosing between the unpalatable and the disastrous. A lot of governments experimented with the disastrous in the twentieth century; now the trend seems to be toward the merely unpalatable.Oddly enough, the leaders now are European countries like Belgium, which has a capital gains tax rate of zero.ImmigrationThe other place you could beat the US would be with smarter immigration policy.
paragraphs.translated: 正如加尔布雷思所说，政治就是在不愉快和灾难之间做出选择。许多政府在二十世纪尝试了灾难性的政策；而现在，趋势似乎转向了仅仅是不愉快的选择。出人意料的是，如今的领导者是像比利时这样的欧洲国家，其资本利得税率为零。移民政策另一个可以超越美国的地方是采取更明智的移民政策。

paragraphs.original: There are huge gains to be made here. Silicon valleys are made of people, remember.Like a company whose software runs on Windows, those in the current Silicon Valley are all too aware of the shortcomings of the INS, but there's little they can do about it.
paragraphs.translated: 这里有很大的收益空间。硅谷是由人组成的，记住。就像一家公司的软件运行在Windows上一样，目前在硅谷的人们都非常清楚INS的缺点，但他们对此无能为力。

paragraphs.original: They're hostages of the platform.America's immigration system has never been well run, and since 2001 there has been an additional admixture of paranoia. What fraction of the smart people who want to come to America can even get in?
paragraphs.translated: 他们是平台的人质。美国的移民系统从来都不完善，自2001年以来，又增添了一层偏执的色彩。有多少聪明人想要来美国却连入境的机会都没有？

paragraphs.original: I doubt even half. Which means if you made a competing technology hub that let in all smart people, you'd immediately get more than half the world's top talent, for free.US immigration policy is particularly ill-suited to startups, because it reflects a model of work from the 1970s.
paragraphs.translated: 我怀疑甚至有一半。这意味着，如果你建立了一个对所有聪明人开放的竞争性技术中心，你将立即免费获得世界上一半以上顶尖人才。美国的移民政策尤其不适合初创企业，因为它反映的是20世纪70年代的工作模式。

paragraphs.original: It assumes good technical people have college degrees, and that work means working for a big company.If you don't have a college degree you can't get an H1B visa, the type usually issued to programmers.
paragraphs.translated: 它认为优秀的技术人才应该有大学学位，并且工作就意味着为大公司工作。如果你没有大学学位，你就无法获得H1B签证，这种签证通常是发给程序员的。

paragraphs.original: But a test that excludes Steve Jobs, Bill Gates, and Michael Dell can't be a good one. Plus you can't get a visa for working on your own company, only for working as an employee of someone else's. And if you want to apply for citizenship you daren't work for a startup at all, because if your sponsor goes out of business, you have to start over.American immigration policy keeps out most smart people, and channels the rest into unproductive jobs.
paragraphs.translated: 但是，一项将史蒂夫·乔布斯、比尔·盖茨和迈克尔·戴尔排除在外的测试不可能是好的。此外，你不能为了自己创业而获得签证，只能为了在别人的公司工作而获得签证。而且，如果你想申请公民身份，你根本不敢在初创公司工作，因为如果你的赞助商倒闭了，你就得从头开始。美国的移民政策排斥了大多数聪明人，并将剩下的人引导到低效的工作中。

paragraphs.original: It would be easy to do better. Imagine if, instead, you treated immigration like recruiting-- if you made a conscious effort to seek out the smartest people and get them to come to your country.A country that got immigration right would have a huge advantage.
paragraphs.translated: 很容易做得更好。想象一下，如果你把移民当作招聘来对待——如果你有意识地寻找最聪明的人，并吸引他们来到你的国家。一个正确处理移民问题的国家将拥有巨大的优势。

paragraphs.original: At this point you could become a mecca for smart people simply by having an immigration system that let them in.A Good VectorIf you look at the kinds of things you have to do to create an environment where startups condense, none are great sacrifices.
paragraphs.translated: 到了这个地步，只要你有一个能让这些人进入的移民系统，你就可以成为智慧人才的圣地。一个好的方向是，如果你看看为了创造一个创业公司能够聚集的环境所需要做的事情，没有哪一件是巨大的牺牲。

paragraphs.original: Great universities? Livable towns? Civil liberties? Flexible employment laws? Immigration policies that let in smart people? Tax laws that encourage growth? It's not as if you have to risk destroying your country to get a silicon valley; these are all good things in their own right.And then of course there's the question, can you afford not to?
paragraphs.translated: 伟大的大学？宜居的城镇？公民自由？灵活的就业法律？吸引聪明人的移民政策？鼓励增长的税收法律？你并不需要冒着毁掉国家的风险来获得一个硅谷；这些本身就都是好东西。当然，还有一个问题是，你能否承担不起这样做？

paragraphs.original: I can imagine a future in which the default choice of ambitious young people is to start their own company rather than work for someone else's. I'm not sure that will happen, but it's where the trend points now.
paragraphs.translated: 我可以设想一个未来，那时有志向的年轻人的默认选择是自己创业，而不是为别人工作。我不确定这是否会成为现实，但目前的趋势确实指向了这个方向。

paragraphs.original: And if that is the future, places that don't have startups will be a whole step behind, like those that missed the Industrial Revolution.Notes[1] On the verge of the Industrial Revolution, England was already the richest country in the world.
paragraphs.translated: 如果这是未来，那么没有创业公司的地区将落后一步，就像那些错过了工业革命的地区一样。注[1] 在工业革命前夕，英国已经是世界上最富有的国家。

paragraphs.original: As far as such things can be compared, per capita income in England in 1750 was higher than India's in 1960.Deane, Phyllis, The First Industrial Revolution, Cambridge University Press, 1965.[2] This has already happened once in China, during the Ming Dynasty, when the country turned its back on industrialization at the command of the court.
paragraphs.translated: 就这类事情可以比较而言，1750年英格兰的人均收入高于1960年的印度。迪恩，菲莉丝，《第一次工业革命》，剑桥大学出版社，1965年。[2]这种情况已经在中国发生过一次，即明朝时期，当时国家在朝廷的命令下放弃了工业化。

paragraphs.original: One of Europe's advantages was that it had no government powerful enough to do that.[3] Of course, Feynman and Diogenes were from adjacent traditions, but Confucius, though more polite, was no more willing to be told what to think.[4] For similar reasons it might be a lost cause to try to establish a silicon valley in Israel.
paragraphs.translated: 欧洲的一个优势在于，它没有一个强大到足以做到这一点的政府。[3] 当然，费曼和第欧根尼来自相邻的传统，但孔子虽然更加礼貌，却同样不愿意被人告知如何思考。[4] 出于类似的原因，试图在以色列建立一个硅谷可能是个徒劳之举。

paragraphs.original: Instead of no Jews moving there, only Jews would move there, and I don't think you could build a silicon valley out of just Jews any more than you could out of just Japanese.(This is not a remark about the qualities of these groups, just their sizes.
paragraphs.translated: 并不是没有犹太人会搬到那里，而是只有犹太人会搬到那里，而且我认为你不可能仅靠犹太人建立一个硅谷，就像你不能仅靠日本人建立一个硅谷一样。（这并不是对这些群体品质的评论，只是关于他们数量的考量。

paragraphs.original: Japanese are only about 2% of the world population, and Jews about .2%.)[5] According to the World Bank, the initial capital requirement for German companies is 47.6% of the per capita income. Doh.World Bank, Doing Business in 2006, http://doingbusiness.org[6] For most of the twentieth century, Europeans looked back on the summer of 1914 as if they'd been living in a dream world.
paragraphs.translated: 日本人仅占世界人口的约2%，犹太人则约为0.2%。根据世界银行的数据，德国公司的初始资本要求为人均收入的47.6%。世界银行，2006年营商环境报告，http://doingbusiness.org 在20世纪的大部分时间里，欧洲人回顾1914年夏天时，仿佛他们曾生活在一个梦幻般的世界。

paragraphs.original: It seems more accurate (or at least, as accurate) to call the years after 1914 a nightmare than to call those before a dream. A lot of the optimism Europeans consider distinctly American is simply what they too were feeling in 1914.[7] The point where things start to go wrong seems to be about 50%.
paragraphs.translated: 将1914年之后的岁月称为噩梦似乎更为准确（或者至少同样准确），而不是将此前的岁月称为美梦。欧洲人认为独具美国特色的许多乐观情绪，实际上在1914年时他们自己也有同感。事情开始出错的转折点似乎是在大约50%的时候。

paragraphs.original: Above that people get serious about tax avoidance. The reason is that the payoff for avoiding tax grows hyperexponentially (x/1-x for 0 < x < 1). If your income tax rate is 10%, moving to Monaco would only give you 11% more income, which wouldn't even cover the extra cost.
paragraphs.translated: 人们开始认真对待避税。原因是避税的收益呈超指数增长（对于 0 < x < 1，其增长率为 x/1-x）。如果你的所得税率为 10%，搬到摩纳哥只会让你的收入增加 11%，这还不足以抵消额外的成本。

paragraphs.original: If it's 90%, you'd get ten times as much income. And at 98%, as it was briefly in Britain in the 70s, moving to Monaco would give you fifty times as much income. It seems quite likely that European governments of the 70s never drew this curve.Thanks to Trevor Blackwell, Matthias Felleisen, Jessica Livingston, Robert Morris, Neil Rimer, Hugues Steinier, Brad Templeton, Fred Wilson, and Stephen Wolfram for reading drafts of this, and to Ed Dumbill for inviting me to speak.French TranslationRussian TranslationJapanese TranslationArabic Translation
